possibilities: Listening to music or the radio
Attending a presentation, conference, or class
Computer, Internet or Email|google, facebook, twitter, social network

subQuestions.text: What kind of noise is around?
How many people are there?
How many people are you interacting with?
How focused were you on what you were doing?
How absorbed were you in what you were doing?
How aware were you that your mind was wandering?
hints: The phone might have helped me notice

subQuestions.text: Were you thinking in words?
Were you thinking with visual images?
Were you thinking with sounds?
If you were not focused but also not experiencing any of the linguistic/visual/auditory features above, were you...?
Who were you thinking about?
How controlled was your thought?
How do you feel?
How far into the past or the future were you thinking about?
How new was your thought?

details.text: How long have done these activities today?

subQuestions.text: How long have you slept
How vivid were your dreams?
hints: Parts of my dreams were clear

subQuestions.text: How were your dreams?
I could be experiencing some emotion and not be conscious of it until some time later.
I break or spill things because of carelessness, not paying attention, or thinking of something else.
I find it difficult to stay focused on what’s happening in the present.
I tend to walk quickly to get where I’m going without paying attention to what I experience along the way.
I tend not to notice feelings of physical tension or discomfort until they really grab my attention.
I forget a person’s name almost as soon as I’ve been told it for the first time.
It seems I am “running on automatic” without much awareness of what I’m doing.
I rush through activities without being really attentive to them.
I get so focused on the goal I want to achieve that I lose touch with what I am doing right now to get there.
I do jobs or tasks automatically, without being aware of what I’m doing.
I find myself listening to someone with one ear, doing something else at the same time.
I drive/walk places on “automatic pilot” and then wonder why I went there.
I find myself preoccupied with the future or the past.
I find myself doing things without paying attention.
I snack without being aware that I’m eating.
My attention is often focused on aspects of myself I wish I'd stop thinking about.
I always seem to be rehashing in my mind recent things I've said or done.
Sometimes it is hard for me to shut off thoughts about myself.
Long after an argument or disagreement is over with, my thoughts keep going back to what happened.
I tend to
or dwell over things that happen to me for a really long time afterward.
I don't waste time rethinking things that are over and done with.
Often I'm playing back over in my mind how I acted in a past situation.
I often find myself reevaluating something I've done.
I never ruminate or dwell on myself for very long.
It is easy for me to put unwanted thoughts out of my mind.
I often reflect on episodes in my life that I should no longer concern myself with.
I spent a great deal of time thinking back over my embarrassing or disappointing moments.
Philosophical or abstract thinking doesn't appeal to me that much.
I'm not really a meditative type of person.
I love exploring my 'inner' self.
My attitudes and feelings about things fascinate me.
I don't really care for introspective or self-reflective thinking.
I love analyzing why I do things.
People often say I'm a 'deep', introspective type of person.
I don't care much for self-analysis.
I'm very self-inquisitive by nature.
I love to meditate on the nature and meaning of things.
I often love to look at my life in philosophical ways.
Contemplating myself isn't my idea of fun.
I have difficulty staying mentally engaged when I participate in routine tasks.
My mind wanders off.
I have periods when I feel like I am detached or separate from my body.
There are occasions when I discover that I have done something even though I have no recollection of doing it.
There are times when places that were once familiar to me appear strange or different.
There are periods when I experience myself as having different personalities.
I take comfort in retreating into my own inner world.
There are times when I feel I have little control over my actions or behavior.
When I listen to people speak, I “space out” or have difficulty attending to what they say.
There are times when I feel like I am in a daze or trance.
There are times when I have difficulty distinguishing what I thought about doing from what I actually did do.
There are periods during which I “lose time,” or am unaware of what happened during extended periods of time.
I engage in daydreaming.
I feel numb.
I find things in my possession which I don't remember acquiring.
There are times when I feel a deep, dark void within me.
There are periods when I lose my sense of how much time has gone by.
There are occasions when people who I know momentarily seem unfamiliar to me.
I have difficulty focusing my attention or concentration for long periods of time.
There are times when I find myself emerge from a period during which I had clearly been doing something, but I cannot remember what it was that I was doing.
I have feelings of emptiness.
I am bothered by not having a clear sense of who I really am.
There are occasions when I have the experience of hearing sounds associated with my past, even though there is nothing in my present environment that produced those sounds.
I have experiences where I find myself questioning if aspects of the environment I am in are real.
When I imagine experiences or events or when I daydream, it seems like what I am imagining is actually occurring.

glossary.Imagery: When you imagine images in your head.
glossary.Cupcake: also British English: fairy cake; Australian English: fairy cake patty cake or cup cake) is a small cake designed to serve one person, which may be baked in a small thin paper or aluminium cup. As with larger cakes, icing and other cake decorations, such as sprinkles, may be applied.
glossary.Daydreaming: Daydreaming is a short-term detachment from one's immediate surroundings, during which a person's contact with reality is blurred and partially substituted by a visionary fantasy, especially one of happy, pleasant thoughts, hopes or ambitions, imagined as coming to pass, and experienced while awake.
glossary.Mind-wandering: Mind-wandering (sometimes referred to as task-unrelated thought) is the experience of thoughts not remaining on a single topic for a long period of time, particularly when people are not engaged in an attention-demanding task. Mind-wandering tends to occur during driving, reading and other activities where vigilance may be low.
glossary.mood: Emotional state, can be happy, sad, etc
